title: US Workforce AI Exposure
description: Share of US jobs with significant task overlap with current AI capabilities. Exposure measures what AI could automate, not what it has. High exposure does not equal displacement.

sources.title: The Potentially Large Effects of AI on Economic Growth
sources.excerpt: Roughly two-thirds of current jobs are exposed to some degree of AI automation; generative AI could substitute up to one-fourth of current work.

sources.title: OECD Employment Outlook 2023: AI and the Labour Market
sources.excerpt: 27% of jobs are in occupations at high risk of automation across OECD countries.

sources.title: Gen-AI: Artificial Intelligence and the Future of Work
sources.excerpt: Almost 40% of global employment is exposed to AI, with advanced economies more affected.

sources.title: GPTs are GPTs: An Early Look at the Labor Market Impact Potential of LLMs
sources.excerpt: ~80% of the US workforce could have at least 10% of their tasks affected by GPTs; ~19% of workers may see at least 50% of tasks impacted.

sources.title: Projected Impact of Generative AI on Future Productivity Growth
sources.excerpt: In about 40% of employment in exposed occupations, at least 50% of tasks will be replaceable by AI within 10 years.

sources.title: The Anthropic Economic Index: Economic Primitives
sources.excerpt: 49% of jobs now use AI for at least 25% of their tasks (up from 36% in early 2025); augmentation (52%) has overtaken automation (45%) as primary use pattern.

sources.title: AI exposure predicts unemployment risk
sources.excerpt: Workers in AI-exposed occupations face significantly higher unemployment risk.

sources.title: AI and jobs: A review of theory, estimates, and evidence
sources.excerpt: Productivity gains 20-60% in controlled RCTs, 15-30% in field experiments; AI exposure measures converge toward high-wage jobs being most exposed.
